articles.headline: At SAC, Rules Compliance With an ‘Edge’
articles.snippet: SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund now facing criminal charges, is proud of its “strong culture of compliance” with insider-trading rules, but the government’s indictment shows little evidence of it.
articles.abstract: SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund now facing criminal charges, is proud of its “strong culture of compliance” with insider-trading rules, but the government’s indictment shows little evidence of it.
articles.lead_paragraph: According to SAC Capital Advisors, the wildly successful hedge fund now accused of systematic crime, the firm not only has “a strong culture of compliance” intended to “deter insider trading,” as the firm put it recently, but may also have one of the most rigorous and “cutting edge” hedge fund compliance programs in the country.

articles.headline: In the Beginning Was the Word; Now the Word Is on an App
articles.snippet: With more than 100 million downloads, YouVersion, a free app that offers over 600 Bible translations, has found itself in the company of successful start-ups like Instagram and Dropbox.
articles.abstract: With more than 100 million downloads, YouVersion, a free app that offers over 600 Bible translations, has found itself in the company of successful start-ups like Instagram and Dropbox.
articles.lead_paragraph: EDMOND, Okla. — More than 500 years after Gutenberg, the Bible is having its i-moment.

articles.headline: Seeking Light in the Heat of Energy Investing
articles.snippet: There’s money to be made by investing in energy, everyone is saying. But as the field grows, how do you separate winners from flashes in the pan?
articles.abstract: There’s money to be made by investing in energy, everyone is saying. But as the field grows, how do you separate winners from flashes in the pan?
articles.lead_paragraph: Energy independence. Oil exports. Fracking. Electric cars. Solar power. And as of last week: the heat dome. These are phrases that are bandied about, sometimes dividing people along political lines. But all mean one thing: this is a boom time for the United States energy sector, from pulling it out of the ground to moving it around the country to finding ways to use less of it.

articles.headline: On Rooftops, a Rival for Utilities
articles.snippet: Big power companies say that incentives for solar power are robbing them of paying customers, setting up a fight for the future of renewable energy.
articles.abstract: Big power companies say that incentives for solar power are robbing them of paying customers, setting up a fight for the future of renewable energy.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, power companies have watched warily as solar panels have sprouted across the nation’s rooftops. Now, in almost panicked tones, they are fighting hard to slow the spread.

articles.headline: Rebirth of Book by Aide to Carter
articles.snippet: Kathleen Jordan, daughter of President Jimmy Carter’s chief of staff Hamilton Jordan, is shepherding her father’s memoir to publication.
articles.abstract: Kathleen Jordan, daughter of President Jimmy Carter’s chief of staff Hamilton Jordan, is shepherding her father’s memoir to publication.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hamilton Jordan, Jimmy Carter’s young, brash chief of staff, was famous during the administration for negotiating tough deals, carousing at night and shunning the stuffy customs of official Washington.

articles.headline: Wild Swings in Markets Fuel Anxiety of Japanese
articles.snippet: After many years of doldrums, the economy in Japan appears to be re-energized and novices are testing the market waters. But volatility may stifle their enthusiasm.
articles.abstract: After many years of doldrums, the economy in Japan appears to be re-energized and novices are testing the market waters. But volatility may stifle their enthusiasm.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Mika Tanabe, a new investor in the Japanese stock market, has been on a stomach-turning roller-coaster ride. Since March, her shares in Softmax, an electronic medical records company, have slumped 30 percent, surged 120 percent, lost half their value, then climbed 20 percent again.

articles.headline: A Trail of Masterpieces and a Web of Lies, Leading to Anguish
articles.snippet: Investigators are still struggling to penetrate the fog of claims and counterclaims about what happened to seven paintings that were stolen by a Romanian criminal gang from a Dutch museum.
articles.abstract: Investigators are still struggling to penetrate the fog of claims and counterclaims about what happened to seven paintings that were stolen by a Romanian criminal gang from a Dutch museum.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARCALIU, Romania — On a snowy day in January, Radu Dogaru, sheltering with a computer at his mother’s house in this remote Romanian village, set out the terms for a deal that had eluded him for months but that now suddenly seemed tantalizingly close.

articles.headline: Quiet Rivalry Over the Next Fed Leader Comes Out of the Shadows
articles.snippet: The choice of the nation’s most powerful technocrat, the head of the Federal Reserve, has rarely generated this much public anticipation or political debate.
articles.abstract: The choice of the nation’s most powerful technocrat, the head of the Federal Reserve, has rarely generated this much public anticipation or political debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three times in the last 35 years, a president has quietly picked a new chairman for the Federal Reserve and then quickly obtained the Senate’s confirmation. The choice of the nation’s most powerful technocrat has far-reaching consequences, but it has rarely generated much public anticipation or political debate.

articles.headline: President-Elect Stirs Optimism in Iran and West
articles.snippet: Hassan Rouhani is concerned about his country’s growing economic troubles and is determined to change policies that have cut off relations with most of the developed world.
articles.abstract: Hassan Rouhani is concerned about his country’s growing economic troubles and is determined to change policies that have cut off relations with most of the developed world.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Bogged down in faltering nuclear talks with the European powers nearly 10 years ago, Hassan Rouhani did something that no Iranian diplomat before or since has managed to do.

articles.headline: Crackdown in Egypt Kills Islamists as They Protest
articles.snippet: The Egyptian authorities unleashed a ferocious attack on Islamist protesters, killing at least 72 people in the second mass killing of demonstrators in three weeks.
articles.abstract: The Egyptian authorities unleashed a ferocious attack on Islamist protesters, killing at least 72 people in the second mass killing of demonstrators in three weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Egyptian authorities unleashed a ferocious attack on Islamist protesters early Saturday, killing at least 72 people in the second mass killing of demonstrators in three weeks and the deadliest attack by the security services since Egypt’s uprising in early 2011.
articles.byline: By Kareem Fahim and Mayy El Sheikh

articles.headline: How to Gauge SAC on the Richter Scale
articles.snippet: SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund facing insider trading charges, has $14 billion under management, but $51 billion in total market exposure. If it unwinds, will that sum roil the stock market?
articles.abstract: SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund facing insider trading charges, has $14 billion under management, but $51 billion in total market exposure. If it unwinds, will that sum roil the stock market?
articles.lead_paragraph: NO major financial firm has survived a criminal indictment, and with SAC Capital Advisors facing insider trading charges, this gigantic hedge fund founded and run by Steven A. Cohen may have to unwind its portfolio. If it does, will the liquidation of its securities roil the stock market?

articles.headline: Obama Says Income Gap Is Fraying U.S. Social Fabric
articles.snippet: Widening income inequality and the weak recovery have undermined Americans’ belief in opportunity, President Obama said in an interview.
articles.abstract: Widening income inequality and the weak recovery have undermined Americans’ belief in opportunity, President Obama said in an interview.
articles.lead_paragraph: GALESBURG, Ill. — In a week when he tried to focus attention on the struggles of the middle class, President Obama said in an interview that he was worried that years of widening income inequality and the lingering effects of the financial crisis had frayed the country’s social fabric and undermined Americans’ belief in opportunity.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: An Afghan Media Mogul, Pushing Boundaries
articles.snippet: Saad Mohseni has brought soap operas, sitcoms and reality TV to his native country, Afghanistan, and with them a modicum of normalcy. Now he is looking to expand to Egypt, Libya and Iraq.
articles.abstract: Saad Mohseni has brought soap operas, sitcoms and reality TV to his native country, Afghanistan, and with them a modicum of normalcy. Now he is looking to expand to Egypt, Libya and Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: AT the inaugural championship of the new Afghan premier soccer league in Kabul last October, Saad Mohseni stood on the well-groomed sideline wearing a Western blazer and a toothy smile that said, “Yes, you had better believe it.”

articles.headline: Worries Mount as Syria Lures West’s Muslims
articles.snippet: Westerners go to Syria motivated by a desire to ease suffering by defeating the government, but there is concern that they will return home with jihadist zeal.
articles.abstract: Westerners go to Syria motivated by a desire to ease suffering by defeating the government, but there is concern that they will return home with jihadist zeal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A rising number of radicalized young Muslims with Western passports are traveling to Syria to fight with the rebels against the government of Bashar al-Assad, raising fears among American and European intelligence officials of a new terrorist threat when the fighters return home.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Senators See an Upside in a Problematic Issue: Abortion
articles.snippet: Senators Marco Rubio, Ted Cruz and Rob Portman are discussing how to advance a bill in the Senate to ban abortion at 20 weeks — an issue that has invigorated the Republican base this year.
articles.abstract: Senators Marco Rubio, Ted Cruz and Rob Portman are discussing how to advance a bill in the Senate to ban abortion at 20 weeks — an issue that has invigorated the Republican base this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It reads like a who’s who of the next generation of Republican Party leaders: Marco Rubio, Ted Cruz, Rob Portman.

articles.headline: Merger Is Set To Create World’s No. 1 Ad Company
articles.snippet: Together, Omnicom Group and the Publicis Groupe would become the world’s biggest advertising company, setting their sights on digital media.
articles.abstract: Together, Omnicom Group and the Publicis Groupe would become the world’s biggest advertising company, setting their sights on digital media.
articles.lead_paragraph: After decades of buying up boutique firms, the advertising conglomerates Omnicom Group and Publicis Groupe finally set their sights on one another.
articles.byline: By Tanzina Vega and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: A Familiar Role for Muslim Brotherhood: Opposition
articles.snippet: The Brotherhood’s only reliable partners now are other Islamist groups whose members may be more willing to use violent or radical tactics.
articles.abstract: The Brotherhood’s only reliable partners now are other Islamist groups whose members may be more willing to use violent or radical tactics.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Among the muddy, crowded tents where tens of thousands of Muslim Brotherhood members have been living for weeks in a vast sit-in protest, men in Islamic dress can still be seen carrying incongruous signs above the teeming crowd: “Liberals for Morsi,” “Christians for Morsi,” “Actors for Morsi.” It is the vestige of a plea for diverse allies in the Brotherhood’s quest to reinstate President Mohamed Morsi, who was ousted by the military on July 3.

articles.headline: PC Industry Fights to Adapt as Tablets Muscle In
articles.snippet: While sales of PCs to businesses remain steady, demand among consumers has plunged, largely because people are instead buying iPads, Kindle Fires and other tablets.
articles.abstract: While sales of PCs to businesses remain steady, demand among consumers has plunged, largely because people are instead buying iPads, Kindle Fires and other tablets.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The death of the personal computer may be an exaggeration. But the industry around personal computers seems to be in limbo.

articles.headline: VCR’s Past Is Guiding Television’s Future
articles.snippet: Cases against two services that change how viewers watch TV are far from settled, but the stakes, which would affect broadcasters’ profits, could not be bigger.
articles.abstract: Cases against two services that change how viewers watch TV are far from settled, but the stakes, which would affect broadcasters’ profits, could not be bigger.
articles.lead_paragraph: The last few weeks have been a rugged legal stretch for incumbent television companies.

articles.headline: Detroit Looks to Health Law to Ease Costs
articles.snippet: As Detroit enters the bankruptcy process, officials say insurance exchanges could pare tens of millions from the $5.7 billion the city owes in retiree health costs.
articles.abstract: As Detroit enters the bankruptcy process, officials say insurance exchanges could pare tens of millions from the $5.7 billion the city owes in retiree health costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Detroit enters the federal bankruptcy process, the city is proposing a controversial plan for paring some of the $5.7 billion it owes in retiree health costs: pushing many of those too young to qualify for Medicare out of city-run coverage and into the new insurance markets that will soon be operating under the Obama health care law.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Abby Goodnough

articles.headline: Two Ad Giants Chasing Google in Merger Deal
articles.snippet: The merger of Omnicom and Publicis signals that advertising is now firmly in the business of collecting and selling the personal information of millions of consumers.
articles.abstract: The merger of Omnicom and Publicis signals that advertising is now firmly in the business of collecting and selling the personal information of millions of consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, the advertising business has been driven by the Madison Avenue mythology of small independent shops coming up with the snappy catchphrase or memorable TV commercial that becomes part of everyday culture.

articles.headline: Jackson’s Earning Potential Is at the Heart of a Wrongful-Death Suit
articles.snippet: The wrongful-death suit against A.E.G. Live hinges on whether Michael Jackson or the company was responsible for hiring the doctor who administered the anesthetic that killed him.
articles.abstract: The wrongful-death suit against A.E.G. Live hinges on whether Michael Jackson or the company was responsible for hiring the doctor who administered the anesthetic that killed him.
articles.lead_paragraph: He is one of the top-grossing artists in music. His influence is heard all over the Top 10, his songs have inspired two hit Cirque du Soleil shows, and Jay Z raps about him obsessively as the ultimate symbol of success.

articles.headline: Momentum Builds Against N.S.A. Surveillance
articles.snippet: The movement to significantly rein in surveillance by the National Security Agency began on the political fringes but has built up support from Republican and Democratic leaders.
articles.abstract: The movement to significantly rein in surveillance by the National Security Agency began on the political fringes but has built up support from Republican and Democratic leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The movement to crack down on government surveillance started with an odd couple from Michigan, Representatives Justin Amash, a young libertarian Republican known even to his friends as “chief wing nut,” and John Conyers Jr., an elder of the liberal left in his 25th House term.

articles.headline: Few Suitors to Build a New Marine One
articles.snippet: The bidding for the helicopter, as well as other recent contract troubles, suggests that the goal of creating sharper competition with government contracts is hard to achieve.
articles.abstract: The bidding for the helicopter, as well as other recent contract troubles, suggests that the goal of creating sharper competition with government contracts is hard to achieve.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wanting to clamp down on wasteful spending, President Obama halted a project to create new presidential helicopters four years ago, saying its soaring price was a symbol of government contracting “gone amok.”

articles.headline: Weak Finish From Europe on Chinese Solar Panels
articles.snippet: The European Commission’s antidumping case against China started vigorously but foundered amid European political divisions; it may ultimately strengthen China’s solar industry.
articles.abstract: The European Commission’s antidumping case against China started vigorously but foundered amid European political divisions; it may ultimately strengthen China’s solar industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The European Commission’s investigation of solar-panel imports from China was the world’s biggest antidumping case when it began last September, signaling a new willingness in Brussels to challenge China’s extensive assistance to favored export-oriented industries.

articles.headline: Aberdeen, With a Foot on the Seafloor
articles.snippet: Since the early 1970s, Aberdeen, Scotland, has evolved from a gritty fishing town into the world’s center of innovation in technology for the offshore energy industry.
articles.abstract: Since the early 1970s, Aberdeen, Scotland, has evolved from a gritty fishing town into the world’s center of innovation in technology for the offshore energy industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABERDEEN, Scotland — Peter Blake has an American employer, the oil giant Chevron, and his work is global. It is his job to pull together and dispatch billions of dollars’ worth of sophisticated undersea equipment needed for oil and natural gas fields in the Gulf of Mexico and offshore from Angola, the Republic of Congo, Indonesia and Australia.

articles.headline: Garry Davis, Man of No Nation Who Saw One World of No War, Dies at 91
articles.snippet: Mr. Davis was a self-declared world citizen who tirelessly advocated to erase national borders and to end wars as part of the One World movement.
articles.abstract: Mr. Davis was a self-declared world citizen who tirelessly advocated to erase national borders and to end wars as part of the One World movement.
articles.lead_paragraph: On May 25, 1948, a former United States Army flier entered the American Embassy in Paris, renounced his American citizenship and, as astonished officials looked on, declared himself a citizen of the world.

articles.headline: Hunting for Luxury, Retail Giant Buys Saks
articles.snippet: Saks Inc. has agreed to sell itself to the Hudson’s Bay Company for about $2.4 billion in cash, uniting the storied luxury retailer with Lord & Taylor and the Canadian chain Hudson’s Bay.
articles.abstract: Saks Inc. has agreed to sell itself to the Hudson’s Bay Company for about $2.4 billion in cash, uniting the storied luxury retailer with Lord & Taylor and the Canadian chain Hudson’s Bay.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:49 p.m. |  When the real estate scion Richard A. Baker acquired the department store chain Lord & Taylor at the market peak in 2006, retail industry players laughed. Mr. Baker, they snickered, was just the latest money guy who would get clobbered trying to break into the fashion business.
articles.byline: By Peter Lattman and Stephanie Clifford

articles.headline: On Gay Priests, Pope Francis Asks, ‘Who Am I to Judge?’
articles.snippet: “If someone is gay and he searches for the Lord and has good will, who am I to judge?” Francis was quoted as saying on Monday.
articles.abstract: “If someone is gay and he searches for the Lord and has good will, who am I to judge?” Francis was quoted as saying on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — For generations, homosexuality has largely been a taboo topic for the Vatican, ignored altogether or treated as “an intrinsic moral evil,” in the words of the previous pope.
